description: From Middle English vers, from a mixture of Old English fers and Old French vers; both from Latin versus (“a line in writing, and in poetry a verse; (originally) row, furrow”), from vertō (“to turn around”).

entries.meaning: A poetic form with regular meter and a fixed rhyme scheme.
examples: Restoration literature is well known for its carefully constructed verse.
The restrictions of verse have been steadily relaxed over time.

entries.meaning: One of several similar units of a song, consisting of several lines, generally rhymed.
examples: Note the shift in tone between the first verse and the second.

entries.meaning: A small section of a holy book (Bible, Quran etc.)
(music) A portion of an anthem to be performed by a single voice to each part.

verbs.description: verse (third-person singular simple present verses, present participle versing, simple past and past participle versed)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To tell in verse, or poetry.
(transitive, figurative) to educate about, to teach about.
examples: He versed us in the finer points of category theory.

description: Back-formation from versus, misconstrued as a third-person singular verb verses.

verbs.description: verse (third-person singular simple present verses, present participle versing, simple past and past participle versed)

entries.meaning: (colloquial, sometimes proscribed) To oppose, to compete against, especially in a video game.
